title: What exactly is the drawback on ressourceless champions?
body:
Not talking about energy, at least they are kinda limited, I talk about champions like {{champion:240}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:421}} etc. 

Those who have absolutely no limitation on their abilities, no ressources to manage, nothing. 

By all logic, they should have a drawback to mana users, right? Just that, in this game, they dont. 

They dont pay with long Cooldowns, they are average at best, while some even have very low Cooldowns. 

So, do they deal less damage? Nope, they do good damage, especially lategame... 

Mobility? CC? Nope, they have it all. 

So what exactly do they give up for having the advantage of being able to spam all their skills? Especially in lane thats a giant advantage over mana using enemys, who might be able to trade at first, but at some point run oom and are at your mercy.

replies.body:
Kled is not the best example as his courage is a very important resource and his cooldowns are not that low.
His Q has 9 seconds cd when mounted and 20 seconds between recharges when dismounted at lvl 1 (scales with Kled's level).
His W is his main trading tool but not the first ability to get maxed and its cooldown at the first level is 14 seconds. It's much harder to trade and gain courage without it. It's not a very reliable ability in the laning phase when you are trying to cs and you can't control when you trigger it as you do so.
His E also has a 14 second cd and his ult has 160 second cd.
I can't talk about the other champions but Kled seems pretty fair

Kled isn't good example especially since he literally IS limited by resourcelessness. When low on HP, only good Kled player can afford being cockier, the rest basically loses three crucial abilities for one not ideal enough to consider it no limutation at all. Not to mentoin he can't even freely jump from unmounted form to mounted should he lose Skaarl twice in brawl.

So the resourcelessness itself has limitation even without considering his CDs.

Some is itemisation; eg. Kat or Vlad don't build Morello even though they'd like to. 

Others are that the champion usually pays tradeoffs for being manaless and have strengths and weaknesses associated with it. eg. Resourceless ranged harrass is usually good early game, but mana becomes a non-gate late game and so its relative value decreases over game time. This is essentially declaring that we want the champion to be good early game.

What would you say is Yasuo's trade-off specifically for being resourceless?

You already mentioned stuff like mana builds not being as efficient on Yasuo (he does fine because he builds around it and has historically been unhealthy when he builds Triforce). I am more curious **(genuinely)** about the specific trade-offs that Yasuo "pays" for being manaless, therefore justifying him lacking a mana bar.

I know that hating Yasuo is big meme big boyz but he's genuinely probably the best resourceless design in the entire game. His abilities aren't tied to a resource, but they're all gated in other ways (aside from windwall and it at least has a really long cooldown.)

And the big trade-off Yasuo makes is sacrificing control. He can't decide when to use his shield, and it's easy to force him to waste it by just poking him with an autoattack. To use his tornado, he has to land two Qs and he has to use it almost immediately because his Q stacks don't last very long especially since they got nerfed. Furthermore, to stack his Q in lane he has to push the wave. His E gives him a lot of mobility, but only situationally and only ever in the direction of the enemy, and it also forces him to push the wave which he really doesn't want to do because if the enemy's minions are under tower, he has nothing to use his E on. His ultimate has the _huge_ limitation that it can only be used on an airborne enemy, which means that a significant amount of the time he basically just has 3 abilities.

Compare this to someone like Riven who is a really, really shit design for a resourceless character. All of her abilities are on-demand. They have no restrictions other than cooldowns (and her cooldowns barely even matter these days considering that virtually every item in the entire fucking game gives CDR now). She doesn't concede any control to her opponent like Yasuo does and she doesn't have any real windows of opportunity like he does because all she has to care about are her (not very long) cooldowns and her abilites have no conditional power.

**I'm asking about the intended trade-offs for him being manaless** and I'd like to keep the conversation in that direction.

He can activate his ult **with all displacements,** not just knock-ups. Because **he also has a reliable way to knock people up by himself** (E+Q combo), the condition to activate it is not tied to him being manaless in my opinion. Most champions require certain criteria for their ults to be effective (Veigar has to land his combo to kill a target, Olaf needs to be fighting against CC for the ult to be effective, Tahm needs someone to go inside him to get the most value out of his ult, Jhin needs the targets to be low health). Yes, Yasuo's Ult is tied to a condition, but that condition is not a "cost" for him being manaless. 

The same goes for the rest of his kit btw, Rakan, Jax, Braum, Xin Zao, Fizz and Vi have conditional mobility but they use mana. Most champions that have AoE on their kits push wave when trading but they use mana. **Tristana pushes wave for CSing even if she doesn't want to and she uses mana**. Therefore pushing wave for trading and CSing is not a manaless scpefiic "cost" for being manaless.

Lastly, you say his empowered Q --where a chunk of his damage you propose -- comes from is tied to the condition of proking Q twice beforehand. Well Azir needs to use first W to use his abilities, Le Blanc needs to land a spell for the next one to be empowered,** Annie needs to use FOUR spells to get the most value out of them**, Veigar needs to land his E in order to land his W. Therefore, this type of constrain is not a cost that is paid specifically just by manaless champions

**EDIT:** Sorry forgot the shield proking when you don't want it to: Malzahar, Rakan, Sejuani, Galio, Malphite, Anivia and Volibear all use mana

Okay? I never said anything about all of those conditions being specific to Yasuo. It doesn't matter that not every champion that shares one of those conditions is also manaless.

There doesn't have to be any one specific trade-off that comes exclusively from being manaless. Not requiring mana is just part of a champions power budget. Yasuo has drawbacks for being resourceless. Just because other champions that aren't resourceless have one or more similar drawbacks as a part of their power budget doesn't mean that he isn't still paying for that as a part of his

Also, just to address the points about Yasuo's kit, I'm aware that his ult activates off of any displacement. That's why I said "airborne" (which is what the ability itself calls it) and not "knock-up." You say he has a reliable way to get a knockup by himself, but he doesn't, because he still has to get his Q stacks before he can do his E-Q (and his E-Q actually isn't guaranteed to land, his dash goes a fixed distance that is longer than the radius of E-Q and he also has to wait for his dashing animation, so it is absolutely possible for it to whiff.)

Also there are other champions that require certain criteria for their ults to be used to their greatest effectiveness, but few that require them to be used _at all_, even sub-optimally.

You say that this isn't a cost for him being manaless, but as I previously stated, it absolutely is. Just because other champions make the same trade-off for different benefits does not mean that it isn't still a trade-off.

You go on to point out how other champs share one of his drawbacks, looking at each one in a vacuum instead of seeing how all of Yasuo's drawbacks cumulatively affect him. Yes, other champs have conditional mobility, other champs are forced to push the wave when they don't want to, other champs use stacking mechanics, etc. But the combination of these things on Yasuo (rather than just looking at each one individually and how "oh X champ also has this one drawback") forces him to concede a lot of control to his opponent if he wants to be able to use all of his abilities, and it leaves him with meaningful windows of opportunity despite not having to worry about mana attrition.

did you really need the wall of text?

I'm not debating the E+Q combo as a tool to use ult, it is very reliable. you and I both know it (reliable =/= 100% accuracy)

You talk about Yasuo having meaningful window of opportunity to be traded with (that being his cost for power budget). as well as him ceding control to his opponent. Yet on mid lane (his intended lane during design) he beats around 70% of all mages, and actually is really dominant during laning phase given how short his CDs are and his ability to mitigate damage with his passive and W (which costs his opponent mana and pushes him out of lane). If anything it is the opponent who cedes cotnrol, as they have no kill pressure on Yasuo and have to focus on using their mana to farm and push wave back

It's fairly reliable but it's not at all guaranteed. You have to be able to get in dashing range of someone to be able to use it and the animation of his dash as well as the very lengthy animation of his spin leaves him pretty vulnerable to getting CC'd by a teammate, which prevents him from ulting (anyone who has played Yasuo for any extended period of time will have had this happen to them _very often_.) And again, you also still have to have gotten your 2 stacks to begin with and they can't have expired, which dramatically reduces it's reliability.

> You talk about Yasuo having meaningful window of opportunity to be traded with (that being his cost for power budget). as well as him ceding control to his opponent. Yet on mid lane (his intended lane during design) he beats around 70% of all mages, and actually is really dominant during laning phase given how short his CDs are and his ability to mitigate damage with his passive and W (which costs his opponent mana and pushes him out of lane). If anything it is the opponent who cedes cotnrol, as they have no kill pressure on Yasuo and have to focus on using their mana to farm and push wave back

That's largely because most mage players don't actually try to play around him. They just play like they were fighting another mage, expecting to be able to casually harass him at their leisure and fish for a kill combo all day long. People don't exploit any of his downtime because they don't change their playstyle to combat him, and mages don't have the numbers to just flex him to death regardless like many toplaners do.

Also you'll notice that Yasuo doesn't do very well at higher levels of play. This is precisely because he isn't very reliable and his kit is easy to exploit if you actually understand how to manipulate the wave and pay attention to when he's weak (I.E. no Q stacks, minions near your tower, recently popped shield etc.) which again, the vast majority of people who play the game just don't.

Silence and run away deja-vu style, and heal it all back up while he gets immense damage reduction and tenacity if you try to all-in him (That W is the most powerful defensive steroid in the game, by the way, and it's not even on a damn tank). Also, you probably haven't had to deal with difficult Garens often. Especially since in higher elos (unlike down here) people rarely pick Jhin into a beefy team comp, and instead do the smart thing and pick a DPS carry.

Garen may not be an issue for you mid laners in Diamond, but he sure is an issue when your ADC decides to lock in something that can't build BoRK, and thus he's basically unkillable after 2 and a half items.
